justification: The article proposes MER-WOAs as an advanced method to analyze advice taking behavior, capturing temporal consistency and individual differences, addressing limitations of traditional ratio-of-differences (ROD) indices.
This formula measures the relative adjustment of initial judgments towards advice, indicating the degree of advice taken, by calculating the ratio of differences between judgments and advice.
The model is used to capture differential anchoring and adjustment processes in a regression framework, addressing limitations of simple arithmetic approaches.

measured_by: Mixed-effects regression model revisiting Logg et al. (2019) data
justification: The reanalysis using this model provided evidence that laypersons and experts treated algorithmic versus human advice differently, though the original findings were partially extended.

measured_by: Regression-based model of advice taking without initial judgments
justification: The model captures the informational influence along sequential chains, showing that initial judgments were not a prerequisite for estimating advice weighting, unlike traditional methods.

measured_by: Multiple regression model with separate weights for individual pieces of advice
justification: This model allows for estimating distinct weights given to advice from multiple advisors, offering a more nuanced view compared to simplistic total weighting methods.

measured_by: Multivariate multilevel regression incorporating judgment shift and confidence change
justification: The proposed method simultaneously captures advice utilization on judgment shift and confidence dimensions, enriching traditional measures that only focus on judgmental shifts.
